case_vignette: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the    emergency department 3 hours after having a 2-minute episode of violent, jerky movements of his right arm at school. He was    sweating    profusely during the episode and did  not lose consciou   sness. He remembers having felt a chill  down his spine before the episode. Following the episode, he experienced weakness in the    right arm and was not able to lift it above hi s head for 2 hours. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved with over-the-counter medication.    He   was born at term and his mother remembers him    having an episode of jerky movements when h  e had a high-grade fever as a toddler. There is no fa   mily hist  ory of serious illness, although his father passed away i   n  a motor vehicle accident approximately 1 year ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure  is 94/54 mm Hg. Physical and neur   ologic examina  tions show no abnormalities. A complete blood co   unt and serum concentrations of glucos e, electr olyt   es, calcium, and creatinine are within the reference range.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I had a 2-minute episode where my right arm was moving violently and jerkily, and during the episode, I was sweating a lot. Before it happened, I felt a chill down my spine. After the episode, my right arm felt weak, and I couldn't lift it above my head for a couple of hours.
Did you experience any alteration in consciousness or confusion during or after the episode?
No, I did not lose consciousness during the episode.
Have you experienced any similar episodes before, or was this the first time?
Yes, I had a similar episode of jerky movements when I had a high fever as a toddler.
Do you have a family history of similar episodes or any neurological conditions like epilepsy?
No, there is no family history of serious illness or neurological conditions like epilepsy.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you recently started any new medication?
No, I am not currently taking any medications.
Final Diagnosis: Focal Seizure
